sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving coordination compounds.
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction of [Co(H2O)6]Cl2 and NaOH using the following balanced chemical equation and given standard enthalpies of formation:
[Co(H2O)6]Cl2 (aq) + 2NaOH (aq) → [Co(H2O)6](OH)2 (s) + 2NaCl (aq)
ΔH°f [Co(H2O)6]Cl2 (aq) = -415.32 kJ/mol
ΔH°f [Co(H2O)6](OH)2 (s) = -1276.24 kJ/mol
ΔH°f NaCl (aq) = -407.33 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following formula:

ΔH°rxn = Σ ΔH°f (products) - Σ ΔH°f (reactants)

For the products, we have:
1 mol of [Co(H2O)6](OH)2 (s) with ΔH°f = -1276.24 kJ/mol
2 mol of NaCl (aq) with ΔH°f = -407.33 kJ/mol

For the reactants, we have:
1 mol of [Co(H2O)6]Cl2 (aq) with ΔH°f = -415.32 kJ/mol
2 mol of NaOH (aq) with ΔH°f = -469.15 kJ/mol (not given in the problem, but this value is commonly known)

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

ΔH°rxn = (1 × -1276.24 + 2 × -407.33) - (1 × -415.32 + 2 × -469.15)
ΔH°rxn = (-1276.24 - 814.66) - (-415.32 - 938.30)
ΔH°rxn = (-2090.90) - (-1353.62)

ΔH°rxn = -737.28 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction of [Co(H2O)6]Cl2 and NaOH is -737.28 kJ/mol.
